trans-unit.source: A prototype is an object used to implement structure, state, and behavior inheritance in ECMAScript. When a constructor creates an object, that object implicitly references the constructor’s associated prototype for the purpose of resolving property references. The constructor’s associated prototype can be referenced by the program expression constructor.prototype, and properties added to an object’s prototype are shared, through inheritance, by all objects sharing the prototype.
trans-unit.target: åŸå‹æ˜¯ç”¨äºåœ¨ECMAScriptä¸­å®ç°ç»“æ„ï¼ŒçŠ¶æ€å’Œè¡Œä¸ºç»§æ‰¿çš„å¯¹è±¡ã€‚å½“æ„é€ å‡½æ•°åˆ›å»ºå¯¹è±¡æ—¶ï¼Œè¯¥å¯¹è±¡éšå¼å¼•ç”¨æ„é€ å‡½æ•°çš„å…³è”åŸå‹ï¼Œä»¥è§£å†³å±æ€§å¼•ç”¨çš„é—®é¢˜ã€‚æ„é€ è¡¨è¾¾å¼çš„å…³è”åŸå‹å¯ä»¥ç”±ç¨‹åºè¡¨è¾¾å¼æ„é€ å™¨.prototypeå¼•ç”¨ï¼Œæ·»åŠ åˆ°å¯¹è±¡åŸå‹çš„å±æ€§å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡ç»§æ‰¿ç”±å…±äº«åŸå‹çš„æ‰€æœ‰å¯¹è±¡å…±äº«ã€‚

trans-unit.source: An object structure is represented as a pair of curly brackets surrounding zero or more name/value pairs (or members). A name is a string. A single colon comes after each name, separating the name from the value. A single comma separates a value from a following name. The names within an object SHOULD be unique.
trans-unit.target: å¯¹è±¡ç»“æ„è¡¨ç¤ºä¸ºä¸€å¯¹å¤§æ‹¬å·ï¼ŒåŒ…å›´ç€é›¶ä¸ªæˆ–å¤šä¸ªåç§°/å€¼å¯¹ï¼ˆæˆ–æˆå‘˜ï¼‰ã€‚åç§°æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªåç§°åéƒ½æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªå†’å·ï¼Œå°†åç§°ä¸å€¼åˆ†å¼€ã€‚å•ä¸ªé€—å·å°†å€¼ä¸åé¢çš„åç§°åˆ†å¼€ã€‚å¯¹è±¡ä¸­çš„åç§°åº”å”¯ä¸€ã€‚

trans-unit.source: ECMAScript has grown to be one of the world's most widely used general purpose programming languages. It is best known as the language embedded in web browsers but has also been widely adopted for server and embedded applications.ECMAScript is based on several originating technologies, the most well-known being JavaScript (Netscape Communications)) and JScript (Microsoft Corporation).). Though before 1994, ECMA was known as "European Computer Manufacturers Association", after 1994, when the organization became global, the "trademark" "Ecma" was kept for historical reasons.
trans-unit.target: ECMAScriptå·²æˆé•¿ä¸ºä¸–ç•Œä¸Šä½¿ç”¨æœ€å¹¿æ³›çš„é€šç”¨ç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€ä¹‹ä¸€ã€‚å®ƒæ˜¯ä¼—æ‰€å‘¨çŸ¥çš„åµŒå…¥åœ¨Webæµè§ˆå™¨ä¸­çš„è¯­è¨€ï¼Œä½†ä¹Ÿå·²å¹¿æ³›ç”¨äºæœåŠ¡å™¨å’ŒåµŒå…¥å¼åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºã€‚ECMAScriptåŸºäºå‡ ç§åŸå§‹æŠ€æœ¯ï¼Œæœ€è‘—åçš„æ˜¯ JavaScript ï¼ˆNetscape Communicationsï¼‰å’Œ JScript ï¼ˆMicrosoft Corporationï¼‰ã€‚å°½ç®¡åœ¨1994å¹´ä¹‹å‰ï¼ŒECMAè¢«ç§°ä¸º“æ¬§æ´²è®¡ç®—æœºåˆ¶é€ å•†åä¼š”ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯åœ¨1994å¹´è¯¥ç»„ç»‡æˆä¸ºå…¨çƒæ€§å…¬å¸ä¹‹åï¼Œç”±äºå†å²åŸå› ä¿ç•™äº†“ Ecma”å•†æ ‡ã€‚

trans-unit.source: ECMAScript supports prototype-based inheritance. Every constructor has an associated prototype, and every object created by that constructor has an implicit reference to the prototype (called the object’s prototype) associated with its constructor. Furthermore, a prototype may have a non-null implicit reference to its prototype, and so on; this is called the prototype chain.
trans-unit.target: ECMAScriptæ”¯æŒåŸºäºåŸå‹çš„ç»§æ‰¿ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªæ„é€ å‡½æ•°éƒ½æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªå…³è”çš„åŸå‹ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”ç”±è¯¥æ„é€ å‡½æ•°åˆ›å»ºçš„æ¯ä¸ªå¯¹è±¡éƒ½æœ‰å¯¹å…¶ä¸å…¶æ„é€ å‡½æ•°å…³è”çš„åŸå‹ï¼ˆç§°ä¸ºå¯¹è±¡çš„åŸå‹ï¼‰çš„éšå¼å¼•ç”¨ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼ŒåŸå‹å¯èƒ½å¯¹å…¶åŸå‹å…·æœ‰énullçš„éšå¼å¼•ç”¨ï¼Œä¾æ­¤ç±»æ¨ï¼›ç­‰ç­‰ã€‚è¿™ç§°ä¸ºåŸå‹é“¾ã€‚

trans-unit.source: In a class-based object-oriented language, in general, state is carried by instances, methods are carried by classes, and inheritance is only of structure and behavior. In ECMAScript, the state and methods are carried by objects, and structure, behavior, and state are all inherited.

JSON has been widely adopted by people who found that it made it a lot easier to produce distributed applications and services. The official Internet media type for JSON is application/json RFC 4627. JSON filenames use the extension .json.

trans-unit.source: JavaScript is a dynamically typed language. That means you don't have to specify the data type of a variable when you declare it, and data types are converted automatically as needed during script execution.

trans-unit.source: All object keys in JSON must be strings. In Javascript object keys can be strings or numbers

All strings in JSON must be quoted in "double quotes". Whereas in Javascript both single quotes and double quotes are allowed. Even with no quotes in the Javascript object notation the object keys are implicitly casted to strings.
An object is an unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs, where a name is a string and a value is a string, number, boolean, null, object, or array.
trans-unit.target: ä¸€ä¸ªå¯¹è±¡æ˜¯é›¶ä¸ªæˆ–å¤šä¸ªåç§°/å€¼å¯¹ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ä¸€ä¸ªåç§°æ˜¯å­—ç¬¦ä¸²çš„æ— åºé›†åˆå’Œä¸€ä¸ªå€¼æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œæ•°å­—ï¼Œå¸ƒå°”å€¼ï¼Œnullï¼Œå¯¹è±¡ï¼Œæˆ–é˜µåˆ—ã€‚

trans-unit.source: An object whose names are all unique is interoperable in the sense that all software implementations receiving that object will agree on the name-value mappings. When the names within an object are not unique, the behavior of software that receives such an object is unpredictable.
trans-unit.target: ä¸€ä¸ªå¯¹è±¡çš„åå­—éƒ½æ˜¯ç‹¬ç‰¹çš„æ˜¯åœ¨è¿™ä¸ªæ„ä¹‰ä¸Šï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰çš„è½¯ä»¶å®ç°æ¥æ”¶äº’æ“ä½œçš„å¯¹è±¡å°†åœ¨åç§°-å€¼æ˜ å°„ä¸€è‡´ã€‚å½“å¯¹è±¡ä¸­çš„åç§°ä¸æ˜¯å”¯ä¸€çš„æ—¶ï¼Œæ¥æ”¶åˆ°è¯¥å¯¹è±¡çš„è½¯ä»¶çš„è¡Œä¸ºæ˜¯ä¸å¯é¢„æµ‹çš„ã€‚

trans-unit.source: Data can be stored in many ways, but if it should be stored in a text file and be readable by a computer, it needs to follow some structure. JSON is one of the many formats that define such a structure.

Dialects have been derived from the same language. They are are quite similar to each other as they have been derived from the same language but they have undergone some changes. A dialect is a variation in the language itself. It is derived from a single language.
Duplicate keys ({"foo":"bar","foo":"baz"}) produce undefined, implementation-specific results; the JSON specification specifically does not define their semantics
trans-unit.target: é‡å¤çš„é”®ï¼ˆ {"foo":"bar","foo":"baz"} ï¼‰äº§ç”Ÿæœªå®šä¹‰çš„ï¼Œç‰¹å®šäºå®ç°çš„ç»“æœï¼›JSONè§„èŒƒæ²¡æœ‰æ˜ç¡®å®šä¹‰å…¶è¯­ä¹‰

trans-unit.source: Duplicate keys produce defined, specified results (in loose mode, the latter definition replaces the former; in strict mode, it's an error).
ECMAScript is the language, whereas JavaScript, JScript, and even ActionScript are called "Dialects".

Extracts from https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7159

trans-unit.source: First you should know what JSON is:
For example, in JSON all keys must be quoted, while in object literals this is not necessary:

For the ones who still think that RFC are more important than blogs and opinion based misconceptions, let's try to answer clarifying some points. I'm not going to repeat all the correct differences already mentioned in previous answers, here I'm just trying adding value summarizing some crucial part rfc7159

Furthermore, (side-rant...) when people talk about a "JSON Object", they almost always mean data that has the "curly-braces" at the top-level. This corresponds nicely to a javascript object. However, the JSON spec does not require that there be a single "curly-braces" object at the top-level of a JSON string. It is perfectly valid JSON to have a list at the top-level, or even to have just a single value. So, while every "JSON Object" corresponds to valid JSON, not all valid JSON strings correspond to what we would call a "JSON Object"! ( because the string could represent a list or an atomic value )
Here is one surprising difference: you can not use undefined in json and all object fields with undefined values will disappear after JSON.stringify
trans-unit.target: è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªä»¤äººæƒŠè®¶çš„åŒºåˆ«ï¼šæ‚¨ä¸èƒ½åœ¨jsonä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ undefined ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”æ‰€æœ‰å¸¦æœ‰undefinedå€¼çš„å¯¹è±¡å­—æ®µåœ¨ JSON.stringify ä¹‹åéƒ½ä¼šæ¶ˆå¤±ã€‚

trans-unit.source: In JSON a function cannot be defined as a value of an object (since this is Javascript specific). In Javascript this is completely legal.
In JavaScript, object literals can have

In addition to reading the documentation, as @Filix King suggested, I also suggest playing around with the JSONLint online JSON validator. That's how I learned that the keys of JSON objects must be strings.

trans-unit.source: In contrast, JavaScript is a programming language. Of course JavaScript also provides a way to define/describe data, but the syntax is very specific to JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: ç›¸åï¼ŒJavaScriptæ˜¯ä¸€ç§ç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€ã€‚å½“ç„¶ï¼ŒJavaScriptè¿˜æä¾›äº†ä¸€ç§å®šä¹‰/æè¿°æ•°æ®çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯è¯­æ³•éå¸¸ç‰¹å®šäºJavaScriptã€‚

trans-unit.source: In other words, valid JSON is also valid JavaScript object literal notation but not necessarily the other way around.
Information about the browser and computer of your users.
It is language agnostic data-interchange format. The syntax of JSON was inspired by the JavaScript Object Literal notation, but there are differences between them.
Its Image member is an object whose Thumbnail member is an object and whose IDs member is an array of numbers.

trans-unit.source: JS object notation, used in JS to create objects in the code conveniently:
JSON can represent four primitive types (strings, numbers, booleans, and null) and two structured types (objects and arrays).

trans-unit.source: JSON defines a small set of formatting rules for the portable representation of structured data.
JSON has the following syntactical constraints:
JSON is a subset of the object literal notation of JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: JSONæ˜¯JavaScriptçš„å¯¹è±¡æ–‡å­—ç¬¦å·çš„å­é›†ã€‚

trans-unit.source: JSON is a kind of wrapper on "JavaScript Object Notation" which forces users to obey more strict rules for defining the objects. And it does this by limiting the possible object declaration ways provided by JavaScript Object Notation feature.
JSON.parse accepts a String that conforms to the JSON grammar.
JSON.stringify produces a String that conforms to the following JSON grammar.

JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) is a text format for the serialization of structured data. It is derived from the object literals of JavaScript, as defined in the ECMAScript Programming Language Standard, Third Edition [ECMA-262].
trans-unit.target: JavaScript Object Notationï¼ˆJSONï¼‰æ˜¯ç”¨äºç»“æ„åŒ–æ•°æ®åºåˆ—åŒ–çš„æ–‡æœ¬æ ¼å¼ã€‚å®ƒæºè‡ª ECMAScriptç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€æ ‡å‡†ç¬¬ä¸‰ç‰ˆ[ECMA-262]ä¸­å®šä¹‰çš„JavaScript å¯¹è±¡æ–‡å­—ã€‚

Key values must be quoted
Knowing that, just by looking at the syntax, your example is not JSON because of two reasons:

trans-unit.source: Lets clarify first what JSON actually is. JSON is a textual, language-independent data-exchange format, much like XML, CSV or YAML.
trans-unit.target: é¦–å…ˆè®©æˆ‘ä»¬æ¾„æ¸…ä¸€ä¸‹JSONåˆ°åº•æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆã€‚JSONæ˜¯ä¸€ç§æ–‡æœ¬å½¢å¼çš„ï¼Œä¸è¯­è¨€æ— å…³çš„æ•°æ®äº¤æ¢æ ¼å¼ï¼Œéå¸¸ç±»ä¼¼äºXMLï¼ŒCSVæˆ–YAMLã€‚

trans-unit.source: Lets look at the syntactical differences between JSON and JavaScript object literals.
Literals are fixed values, not variables, that you literally provide in your script.
Object Property accessors provide access to an object's properties by using the dot notation or the bracket notation.
trans-unit.target: å¯¹è±¡å±æ€§ è®¿é—®å™¨é€šè¿‡ä½¿ç”¨ç‚¹ç¬¦å·æˆ–æ–¹æ‹¬å·ç¬¦å·æä¾›å¯¹å¯¹è±¡å±æ€§çš„è®¿é—®ã€‚

trans-unit.source: Object keys must be strings (i.e. a character sequence enclosed in double quotes ").
trans-unit.target: å¯¹è±¡é”®å¿…é¡»æ˜¯å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼ˆå³ç”¨åŒå¼•å· " æ‹¬èµ·æ¥çš„å­—ç¬¦åºåˆ—ï¼‰ã€‚

trans-unit.source: Object literal syntax is a very convenient way to create javascript objects
SQL Language - Hibernate MySQL Dialect, Oracle Dialect,.. which have some changes or added functionality.

So basically, the newObject in my example above is an object defined by using JavaScript Objeect Notation; but it is not a 'valid' JSON object because it does not follow the rules that JSON standards require.
String literals, number literals or identifier names as keys (since ES6, keys can now also be computed, which introduces yet another syntax).
Strings must be quoted with " and not '
trans-unit.target: å­—ç¬¦ä¸²å¿…é¡»ç”¨ " è€Œä¸æ˜¯ ' å¼•å·

trans-unit.source: Such formats are typically language-independent, meaning they can be processed by Java, Python, JavaScript, PHP, you name it.

That is, if you're writing JavaScript source code, and not dealing with a string, you're not dealing with JSON. Maybe you received the data as JSON (e.g., via ajax or reading from a file), but once you or a library you're using has parsed it, it's not JSON anymore.

trans-unit.source: The JSON language, which stands for 'Javascript object notation', has its syntax derived from javascript object literal syntax. It is used as a programming language independent textual data transfer format.
trans-unit.target: è¯¥ JSON è¯­è¨€ï¼Œå®ƒä»£è¡¨“JavaScriptå¯¹è±¡ç¬¦å·”ï¼Œå…ˆåä»JavaScriptå¯¹è±¡æ–‡å­—è¯­æ³•æ´¾ç”Ÿå®ƒçš„è¯­æ³•ã€‚å®ƒç”¨ä½œä¸ç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€æ— å…³çš„æ–‡æœ¬æ•°æ®ä¼ è¾“æ ¼å¼ã€‚

trans-unit.source: The JSON object is a single object that contains two functions, parse and stringify, that are used to parse and construct JSON texts.

The JSON spec is a syntax for encoding data as a string. What people call a "JSON Object" ( in javascript ) is really just an ordinary javascript object that has (probably) been de-serialized from a valid JSON string, and can be easily re-serialized as a valid JSON string. This generally means that it contains only data ( and not functions ). It also means that there are no dates, because JSON does not have a date type ( probably the most painful thing about JSON ;)
The data types in JSON are also restricted to the following values:
The names within an object SHOULD be unique. object = begin-object [ member *( value-separator member ) ] end-object

There is really no such thing as a "JSON Object".

trans-unit.source: What is the difference between JSON and Object Literal Notation
Why isn't it a JSON object in this case? Just because it is not defined by using quotation marks?
You cannot assign a function as a value to a "JSON object" (because JSON doesn't define any syntax for functions).
You have a more limited range of values (e.g. no functions allowed)
Your keys are not strings (literals). They are identifier names.

string number object array A literal as: true false null The grammar of Strings changes. They have to be delimited by double quotes, while in JavaScript, you can use single or double quotes interchangeably.

var o = { if: "foo" }; // SyntaxError in ES3 While, using a string literal as a property name (quoting the property name) gives no problems:

â–º JavaScript is the most popular implementation of the ECMAScript Standard. The core features of Javascript are based on the ECMAScript standard, but Javascript also has other additional features that are not in the ECMA specifications/standard. Every browser has a JavaScript interpreter.

â–º JSON Strings must be quoted with " and not '. A string is very much like a C or Java string. Strings should be wrapped in double quotes.

trans-unit.source: â–º JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) is a lightweight, text-based, language-independent data interchange format. JSON has been used to exchange data between applications written in any Programming language.
trans-unit.target: â–ºJavaScript Object Notationï¼ˆ JSON ï¼‰æ˜¯ä¸€ç§è½»é‡ï¼ŒåŸºäºæ–‡æœ¬ï¼Œç‹¬ç«‹äºè¯­è¨€çš„æ•°æ®äº¤æ¢æ ¼å¼ã€‚JSONå·²ç”¨äºåœ¨ä»¥ä»»ä½•ç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€ç¼–å†™çš„åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºä¹‹é—´äº¤æ¢æ•°æ®ã€‚

trans-unit.source: â–º Key values must be quoted, only Strings are allowed for keys. If you use other than String it will convert to String. But not recommended to use keys other than String's. Check an example like this - { 'key':'val' } over RFC 4627 - jsonformatter

trans-unit.source: â–º You have a more limited range of values (e.g. no functions allowed). A value can be a string in double quotes, number, boolean, null, object, or array. These structures can be nested.
